THE MADISON

Dr. Finney Appointed.

MEETING OF ATHLETIC BOARD
Assistant Managers for Track and Lacrosse Teams Elected - Outlook
Bright for Coming Season.

At the regular meeting of the
Athletic Board for February, held
last Monday evening, no business
was transacted, except the election
of assistant managers for the lacrosse and track teams. For the
track team, of which Paul 0. Carter, '13, is manager, Richard Coblentz, '14; Jeffries Brinton, 'i6;
Robert Webb - Peploe, '16, and
Francis K. Read, '16, were elected.
To assist Manager Roger Howell of
the lacrosse team, Alan Castleman,
'14 ; Malcolm Lauchheimer, '14 ;
Hiram Woodward, 'i6; David P.
Platt, 16, and Charles H. Tinges,
'16, were elected.
The Athletic Board pursues the
policy of appointing several assistant managers from the underclasses
to help in running the team. From
these assistants the manager for the
following season is usually picked.
This policy is the fairest and most
reasonable, and it is to be wished
that the competition among the assistants were keener than it really is.
Junior—You're not much for
chicken, are you?
Senior—No, I'm a vegetarian.
—Pennsylvania Punch Bowl.

Among the appointees to Governor Goldsborough's State-Wide-Vice
Commission is Dr. J. T. M. Finney,
the noted surgeon and professor
at the Hopkins Medical School.
Dr. Finney has accepted the appointment, and will probably be the
chairman of the commission. Dr.
William Welch, who is at present
chairman of the Administrative
Committee of the Faculty, has also
been asked to serve on the commission, but has found that he 'cannot spare the time for that purpose.
The object of the State-Wide Cornmission is to look into the conditions of vice in Maryland, and to
suggest methods for bettering the
conditions, of vice, if not completely
wiping it out.
Examinations.

The oral examinations for the degree of doctor of philosophy will
be held next Tuesday, February
II, M the presence of the faculty,
in McCoy Hall. The examinations
are for those who are working for
degrees in either German or
French, and will take place in the
rooms of the Germanic and Romance departments.
The way of the transgressor is
well written up.—Kansas City Journal.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 10, 1913
Notice.

In accordance with a rule adopted
by THE NEWS-LETTER Board on
January 13, 1913, for the purpose
of securing greater promptness in
the turning in of copy, Emory H.
Niles has been suspended from the
board for the period of one month;
said month to begin February 3 and
conclude March 3.
Honoring an Alumnus.

In the last issue of THE NEWSLETTER we had the unpleasant duty
of saying what we thought about
the manner in which the Fifth Regiment-Hopkins Games Committee
had chosen to show its esteem of
Governor Wilson. The acceptance
by the student body of the Inaugural Committee's invitation to send
a delegation to march in the inaugural parade gives us the much more
agreeable duty of saying a few
words about what appears to us an
eminently suitable and dignified
manner of honoring our most distinguished alumnus.
To the cynical and the disillusioned, the idea of marching in a
parade with waving banners and
rolling drums may be only ridiculous and absurd; but to those who
do not have the misfortune to be
cynical and disillusioned, the real
value. which it is possible for such
a display to have must be apparent.
This value consists in the symbolic
character of the display. For the
educated mind, it may not be necessary to have abstract .ideas represented by visible tokens; and there
may even be a few to whom symbols
are only not necessary but not even
helpful. But to the great public at
large an idea means little unless it
has some visible expression; and
there are several ideas which the
marching of college delegations in
Governor Wilson's inaugural procession will drive home to the public consciousness of this country in

LEMMERT

CONFERENCE A SUCCESS
Missionary Meeting at Frederick Stimulating in Every Way— Many Interesting
Speakers From Foreign Lands.

The conference held at Frederick
last Saturday and Sunday, February i and 2, was a success from
every standpoint. The people of'
Frederick seemed united in their efforts to show their hospitality to
the students, so that everyone who
went had a royal good time. But
there was a more serious side to the
gathering together. With such
speakers as Mr. Murray of India,
Dr. Mylrea of Arabia, Mr. Kelly
from Africa, and Dr. Young and
Dr. Li from China, telling of the
great social and religious needs of
their countries,the great work of our
missionaries came with a new aspect
to everyone present. Dr. Li, who is
a Chinese lady doctor and at present
taking graduate work in the medical
department of our University, was
especially interesting as she told of
her work—over 9,000 treatments ir
the first year in her hospital. The
one great outstanding fact of all
the discuSsions, was that socially,
economically and spiritually the
(Treat countries of the East are
changing. The use of American
sewing machines, flour, oil and almost every product is an indication
of the spread of Western civilization. The people of these countries
are abandoning their old faiths
in the light of Western learning
and the time is most pressing for
us as a Christian country to give
them what has made our civilization
possible. In one of the most effective addresses of the two days,
Dr. Headland of Peking University
illustrated this in speaking of "ByProducts of Missions." In broadening our knowledge and deepening
our spirit of service, the conference
was a help to each one who attended.

Scientific Association.

The Scientific Association of the
University met in the physical laboratory lecture room at 4 o'clock
last Wednesday, February 5. The
lecturer was Prof. R. W. Wood,
who addressed the Engineering Society last Monday. The subject of
his discussion was "Liquid Air and
the Production of Low Temperature." Professor Wood spoke of
the increased facility with which
liquid air is obtained today, and of
the purposes to which it • is put.
Liquid air is of immense value in
obtaining low temperatures. To
obtain liquid air, pressure and temperature must be changed, so that
when this liquid air is again released,
P-reat heat is consumed in returning
the air to the gaseous condition, and
low temperature is thus caused by
this consumption of ,heat. Othei
Practical uses of liquid air were also
discussed.

Identity of the "Glee Club Singer" Still
Unknown—Many Replies Received.
Contest Continued Another Week.

Co-eds' Cozy Corner

The contest as to the identity of
the famous "Glee Club Singer" has
aroused more interest than any topic
that has been broached at the University in years. This is almost the
sole subject of conversations at
Walter's Gallery, Levering Hall, the
library, Doc Adam's, and all the
other haunts of the students. Lunch
hour has repeatedly been given over
to heated debates on the subject.
As yet, no unanimity of opinion
has been reached, but a number of
clever replies have been received by
the Contest Editor. The prize for
this week has been awarded to the
contestant who submitted the following, with the request that the
name of the author be withheld:
"The 'Glee Club Singer' is a composite picture of Hubner Rice in
Hilgartner's dress suit, with Sattler's
shoulders, Nelson's legs, Carter's
fob and Short's feet."
Six of the replies named the Hon.
Julian H. Marshall. Because of
lack of space they will not all be
printed. The following gives a general idea of their nature:
"I wish to submit the name of
Mr. Julian Marshall as the original
of the 'Glee Club Singer.' The likeness was apparent at first glance."
Among the others who were honored by being named were Messrs.
James H. Marston, Jr., Milton H.
Wagner, George M. Gillet, Edmund
S. Donoho, Robert J. Scovell, J.
Earle Uhler and Augustus E.Sattler.
One contestant suggested that Mr.
Tappan drew the"Glee Club Singer"
from his own photograph. We
hardly think this is probable, although there may be some likeness.
As the Contest Editor knows from
remarks that have been dropped that
there are a number of other students
who intended to submit replies, it
has been decided to continue the
contest another week and award another prize.
VO- 'Although no replies were received from members of the faculty
last week, the Contest Editor wishes
it to be understood that they are
perfectly eligible to compete. A reply from a member of the faculty
will be given due consideration and
will be awarded the prize if it shows
sufficient merit. The .name will be
withheld if requested.
NoTE—Contestants' replies are
limited to 25 words. Be careful not
to exceed this, as several clever replies had to be thrown in the waste
basket last week because of failure
to observe the regulations.

The lacrosse squad, which has
been practicing regularly now for
more than two months, is in unusually good shape for this time of the
year. Although an unusually large
number of old men are out, never:
theless, many new men are showing
up so well that last year's men will
have to hustle to hold their places.
This has been stated several times
in the daily papers, but no names
have been mentioned.
On the defence, the regulars who
are out at the present time are
Sears, who has been playing goal;
Captain Huck, who plays all positions from inhome to point; Butts
Sutton, who, rumgr has it, is wavering between baseball and lacrosse;
Niles, who has his troubles when.
the attack starts to do things, and
Ellicott, who, according to accounts.
may not be allowed by his family
to play; George Gillet, who is
walking without a cane now, cannot run yet, but he expects to 1):.
out later in the season. The two
substitutes of last year—Price and
Richardson—are showing up very
well. There are two freshmen,
also, who are doing good work in
close defence—Primrose and Hasson. Both have played for City
College and, although they are
green, they will make good men in
time.
The attack has a very promising
bunch .out, and it should be able
to work together to build up a
first-rate machine for this year's
team. The leader is, of course,
Eddie Hulburt, who is also assistant coach of the team; no praise
is needed for Hulburt's remarkable
playing. Toni Troxall, who played
outhome last year, is developing
into a plucky and agile player; he
can shoot a goal from any angle iii
the shortest time possible. Johnny
Knipp, a freshman, is also a good
man, and although little, he has excellent stickwork. Voshell and
Everton, who played mid-field last
year, are out again, and although
not much can be judged of midfield players in the cage, they seem
to be doing well. Max Paulus is
back again playing his usual steady
game. Hollyday, last year's center,
has not, been out so far owing to
pressure of work.
Among the younger men, Randall and Lynch are showing up very
well, as is Evitt, a freshman. Other
men out for the team are Marshall.
Lauchheimer, Nelson, Poole and
Raleigh.

JANUARY 31, 1913.
Editor of Co-Eds' Cozy Corner:
Dear Sir—I read during the past
week that President Remsen had
asked for relief from his duties as
acting president of the University.
The trustees reluctantly allowed him
to go; and have appointed an "Administration Committee" to look
after the duties of the president's
office until they are able to secure
Dr. Remsen's successor.
•
Now on this Committee there
are representatives from all or
nearly all the departments, the medical, scientific, philosophic, graduate,
undergraduate, etc. But the trustees have seemingly given us girls
no thought at all. Don't you really
think, down in your heart of hearts,
that we ought to have a representative on the Committee? How are
we girls going to have our views
considered in matters of importance? Suppose the Committee
should decide on a president with
red hair or with a hooked nose!
Why, we would have no way at all
of expostulating, unless we would
want to follow the example of our
militant sisters in London and Dublin, and go around smashing in the
Dean's transom, Mr. Ball's windows
or Walter's mirrors. And so I want
to ask you to do what you can
through your column to secure us
girls our fair rights, without making us resort to less dignified methods.
Oh, yes! and don't you think it
was a shame about that Indian,
Thorpe? He was such a good-looking fellow, too! I wish he went to
college here. My, but I bet he
would look swell in a black and blue
sweater. I feel so sorry for him.
It is a shame he can't come down
here and play any more in the amateur. sports. I am going to try and
get some donations among the girls
to send him a bouquet.
Respectfully yours,
JEANETTE W. C.
P. S.—Don't send a copy of this
letter to 'Mr. Thorpe. He might
find out where those flowers came
from.

about Fielding?

THE MADISON

Dr. Finney Appointed.

MEETING OF ATHLETIC BOARD
Assistant Managers for Track and Lacrosse Teams Elected - Outlook
Bright for Coming Season.

At the regular meeting of the
Athletic Board for February, held
last Monday evening, no business
was transacted, except the election
of assistant managers for the lacrosse and track teams. For the
track team, of which Paul 0. Carter, '13, is manager, Richard Coblentz, '14; Jeffries Brinton, 'i6;
Robert Webb - Peploe, '16, and
Francis K. Read, '16, were elected.
To assist Manager Roger Howell of
the lacrosse team, Alan Castleman,
'14 ; Malcolm Lauchheimer, '14 ;
Hiram Woodward, 'i6; David P.
Platt, 16, and Charles H. Tinges,
'16, were elected.
The Athletic Board pursues the
policy of appointing several assistant managers from the underclasses
to help in running the team. From
these assistants the manager for the
following season is usually picked.
This policy is the fairest and most
reasonable, and it is to be wished
that the competition among the assistants were keener than it really is.
Junior—You're not much for
chicken, are you?
Senior—No, I'm a vegetarian.
—Pennsylvania Punch Bowl.

Among the appointees to Governor Goldsborough's State-Wide-Vice
Commission is Dr. J. T. M. Finney,
the noted surgeon and professor
at the Hopkins Medical School.
Dr. Finney has accepted the appointment, and will probably be the
chairman of the commission. Dr.
William Welch, who is at present
chairman of the Administrative
Committee of the Faculty, has also
been asked to serve on the commission, but has found that he 'cannot spare the time for that purpose.
The object of the State-Wide Cornmission is to look into the conditions of vice in Maryland, and to
suggest methods for bettering the
conditions, of vice, if not completely
wiping it out.
Examinations.

The oral examinations for the degree of doctor of philosophy will
be held next Tuesday, February
II, M the presence of the faculty,
in McCoy Hall. The examinations
are for those who are working for
degrees in either German or
French, and will take place in the
rooms of the Germanic and Romance departments.
The way of the transgressor is
well written up.—Kansas City Journal.

Honoring an Alumnus.

In the last issue of THE NEWSLETTER we had the unpleasant duty
of saying what we thought about
the manner in which the Fifth Regiment-Hopkins Games Committee
had chosen to show its esteem of
Governor Wilson. The acceptance
by the student body of the Inaugural Committee's invitation to send
a delegation to march in the inaugural parade gives us the much more
agreeable duty of saying a few
words about what appears to us an
eminently suitable and dignified
manner of honoring our most distinguished alumnus.
To the cynical and the disillusioned, the idea of marching in a
parade with waving banners and
rolling drums may be only ridiculous and absurd; but to those who
do not have the misfortune to be
cynical and disillusioned, the real
value. which it is possible for such
a display to have must be apparent.
This value consists in the symbolic
character of the display. For the
educated mind, it may not be necessary to have abstract .ideas represented by visible tokens; and there
may even be a few to whom symbols
are only not necessary but not even
helpful. But to the great public at
large an idea means little unless it
has some visible expression; and
there are several ideas which the
marching of college delegations in
Governor Wilson's inaugural procession will drive home to the public consciousness of this country in

CONFERENCE A SUCCESS
Missionary Meeting at Frederick Stimulating in Every Way— Many Interesting
Speakers From Foreign Lands.

The conference held at Frederick
last Saturday and Sunday, February i and 2, was a success from
every standpoint. The people of'
Frederick seemed united in their efforts to show their hospitality to
the students, so that everyone who
went had a royal good time. But
there was a more serious side to the
gathering together. With such
speakers as Mr. Murray of India,
Dr. Mylrea of Arabia, Mr. Kelly
from Africa, and Dr. Young and
Dr. Li from China, telling of the
great social and religious needs of
their countries,the great work of our
missionaries came with a new aspect
to everyone present. Dr. Li, who is
a Chinese lady doctor and at present
taking graduate work in the medical
department of our University, was
especially interesting as she told of
her work—over 9,000 treatments ir
the first year in her hospital. The
one great outstanding fact of all
the discuSsions, was that socially,
economically and spiritually the
(Treat countries of the East are
changing. The use of American
sewing machines, flour, oil and almost every product is an indication
of the spread of Western civilization. The people of these countries
are abandoning their old faiths
in the light of Western learning
and the time is most pressing for
us as a Christian country to give
them what has made our civilization
possible. In one of the most effective addresses of the two days,
Dr. Headland of Peking University
illustrated this in speaking of "ByProducts of Missions." In broadening our knowledge and deepening
our spirit of service, the conference
was a help to each one who attended.

Scientific Association.

The Scientific Association of the
University met in the physical laboratory lecture room at 4 o'clock
last Wednesday, February 5. The
lecturer was Prof. R. W. Wood,
who addressed the Engineering Society last Monday. The subject of
his discussion was "Liquid Air and
the Production of Low Temperature." Professor Wood spoke of
the increased facility with which
liquid air is obtained today, and of
the purposes to which it • is put.
Liquid air is of immense value in
obtaining low temperatures. To
obtain liquid air, pressure and temperature must be changed, so that
when this liquid air is again released,
P-reat heat is consumed in returning
the air to the gaseous condition, and
low temperature is thus caused by
this consumption of ,heat. Othei
Practical uses of liquid air were also
discussed.

Glee Club.

Identity of the "Glee Club Singer" Still
Unknown—Many Replies Received.
Contest Continued Another Week.

Old Stars Will Have to Hustle to Hold
Their Places Against New Men
Many Men Out.

Co-eds' Cozy Corner

The contest as to the identity of
the famous "Glee Club Singer" has
aroused more interest than any topic
that has been broached at the University in years. This is almost the
sole subject of conversations at
Walter's Gallery, Levering Hall, the
library, Doc Adam's, and all the
other haunts of the students. Lunch
hour has repeatedly been given over
to heated debates on the subject.
As yet, no unanimity of opinion
has been reached, but a number of
clever replies have been received by
the Contest Editor. The prize for
this week has been awarded to the
contestant who submitted the following, with the request that the
name of the author be withheld:
"The 'Glee Club Singer' is a composite picture of Hubner Rice in
Hilgartner's dress suit, with Sattler's
shoulders, Nelson's legs, Carter's
fob and Short's feet."
Six of the replies named the Hon.
Julian H. Marshall. Because of
lack of space they will not all be
printed. The following gives a general idea of their nature:
"I wish to submit the name of
Mr. Julian Marshall as the original
of the 'Glee Club Singer.' The likeness was apparent at first glance."
Among the others who were honored by being named were Messrs.
James H. Marston, Jr., Milton H.
Wagner, George M. Gillet, Edmund
S. Donoho, Robert J. Scovell, J.
Earle Uhler and Augustus E.Sattler.
One contestant suggested that Mr.
Tappan drew the"Glee Club Singer"
from his own photograph. We
hardly think this is probable, although there may be some likeness.
As the Contest Editor knows from
remarks that have been dropped that
there are a number of other students
who intended to submit replies, it
has been decided to continue the
contest another week and award another prize.
VO- 'Although no replies were received from members of the faculty
last week, the Contest Editor wishes
it to be understood that they are
perfectly eligible to compete. A reply from a member of the faculty
will be given due consideration and
will be awarded the prize if it shows
sufficient merit. The .name will be
withheld if requested.
NoTE—Contestants' replies are
limited to 25 words. Be careful not
to exceed this, as several clever replies had to be thrown in the waste
basket last week because of failure
to observe the regulations.

The lacrosse squad, which has
been practicing regularly now for
more than two months, is in unusually good shape for this time of the
year. Although an unusually large
number of old men are out, never:
theless, many new men are showing
up so well that last year's men will
have to hustle to hold their places.
This has been stated several times
in the daily papers, but no names
have been mentioned.
On the defence, the regulars who
are out at the present time are
Sears, who has been playing goal;
Captain Huck, who plays all positions from inhome to point; Butts
Sutton, who, rumgr has it, is wavering between baseball and lacrosse;
Niles, who has his troubles when.
the attack starts to do things, and
Ellicott, who, according to accounts.
may not be allowed by his family
to play; George Gillet, who is
walking without a cane now, cannot run yet, but he expects to 1):.
out later in the season. The two
substitutes of last year—Price and
Richardson—are showing up very
well. There are two freshmen,
also, who are doing good work in
close defence—Primrose and Hasson. Both have played for City
College and, although they are
green, they will make good men in
time.
The attack has a very promising
bunch .out, and it should be able
to work together to build up a
first-rate machine for this year's
team. The leader is, of course,
Eddie Hulburt, who is also assistant coach of the team; no praise
is needed for Hulburt's remarkable
playing. Toni Troxall, who played
outhome last year, is developing
into a plucky and agile player; he
can shoot a goal from any angle iii
the shortest time possible. Johnny
Knipp, a freshman, is also a good
man, and although little, he has excellent stickwork. Voshell and
Everton, who played mid-field last
year, are out again, and although
not much can be judged of midfield players in the cage, they seem
to be doing well. Max Paulus is
back again playing his usual steady
game. Hollyday, last year's center,
has not, been out so far owing to
pressure of work.
Among the younger men, Randall and Lynch are showing up very
well, as is Evitt, a freshman. Other
men out for the team are Marshall.
Lauchheimer, Nelson, Poole and
Raleigh.

JANUARY 31, 1913.
Editor of Co-Eds' Cozy Corner:
Dear Sir—I read during the past
week that President Remsen had
asked for relief from his duties as
acting president of the University.
The trustees reluctantly allowed him
to go; and have appointed an "Administration Committee" to look
after the duties of the president's
office until they are able to secure
Dr. Remsen's successor.
•
Now on this Committee there
are representatives from all or
nearly all the departments, the medical, scientific, philosophic, graduate,
undergraduate, etc. But the trustees have seemingly given us girls
no thought at all. Don't you really
think, down in your heart of hearts,
that we ought to have a representative on the Committee? How are
we girls going to have our views
considered in matters of importance? Suppose the Committee
should decide on a president with
red hair or with a hooked nose!
Why, we would have no way at all
of expostulating, unless we would
want to follow the example of our
militant sisters in London and Dublin, and go around smashing in the
Dean's transom, Mr. Ball's windows
or Walter's mirrors. And so I want
to ask you to do what you can
through your column to secure us
girls our fair rights, without making us resort to less dignified methods.
Oh, yes! and don't you think it
was a shame about that Indian,
Thorpe? He was such a good-looking fellow, too! I wish he went to
college here. My, but I bet he
would look swell in a black and blue
sweater. I feel so sorry for him.
It is a shame he can't come down
here and play any more in the amateur. sports. I am going to try and
get some donations among the girls
to send him a bouquet.
Respectfully yours,
JEANETTE W. C.
P. S.—Don't send a copy of this
letter to 'Mr. Thorpe. He might
find out where those flowers came
from.
